title: I owe around 10,000 in credit card debt. I just got a job and I'm afraid to put my check into a bank account.can they take money
question: I owe about 10,000 in credit card debt, most of which is about to drop off in the next year or two. I just got a job working for the state of California. Can they garnish my wages ? if I open a bank account and have direct deposit set up and start putting all my money into that account, can these collection agencys take money from my bank account? I do not owe the IRS any money. once again this is all credit card debt. I'm trying to decide wether or not to try and settle with them for a lower amount and ask them to put in writing that they cant take any money from me if I agree to pay x amount every month...any expertise would be greatly appreciated!!!!
answers: Unless there is a judgment against you no one can take money from you account. If you want pay off the d e bt have an attorney negotiate for you.

Maybe. If creditor has obtained a judgment, they can garnish wages and levy on bank account.
Yes. You may negotiate a payment plan with creditor. Be sure to get it in writing.
Consult BK counsel to review all options.

If the creditor has not filed a lawsuit and obtained a judgment (after your default or after a trial), the creditor cannot levy on your bank account nor can the creditor garnish your wages. The only exception might be if your credit card was issued by the same bank as the bank where you have your bank account. (Called a "banker's setoff.") Do not give the collector direct access to your bank account. I advise against entering into any sort of payment plan. That would re-start the Statute of Limitations. You can save up some money and then offer a lump sum about of a fraction of the amount of their claim. If it has been more than four years since the account went into default, you may have a Statute of Limitations defense if the creditor files a lawsuit. Lastly, do not believe anything that a debt collector tells you, especially if it pertains to your legal rights.

I agree with the above posters in regards to a creditor not being able to garnish your wages absent a valid judgment. It's also important to keep in mind that even if you were to find yourself facing possible garnishment, there are exemptions that you may qualify for.

The written agreement you're referring to sounds like a general settlement agreement, wherein you pay them x dollars and they refrain from litigating the matter and obtaining a judgment in their favor. However, keep in mind that should you enter into such an agreement and default (i.e. miss a payment, late payment, etc), the agreement will likely contain a provision allowing the creditor to obtain a judgment against you for the remainder owing. Should this occur, the creditor will have the ammunition they need to begin garnishment proceedings.

I recommend depositing at a credit union. Data about their customers usually isn't available for sale to collection law firms. Consider getting a free case evaluation to look for illegal collection tactics and YOU may be entitled to compensation!
No one can garnish for consumer debt without first filing a lawsuit. It sound like yours may be time barred.
No, they can't garnish your wages or take money out of your bank account, unless they have a judgment against you first.
